Title: Visual language in Indonesian children film: How Indonesian film makers talk to children
Source title: Interdisciplinary Behavior and Social Sciences - Proceedings of the 3rd International Congress on Interdisciplinary Behavior and Social Sciences, ICIBSoS 2014
Authors with affiliations: Amelia, A., Bina Nusantara International, Jakarta, Indonesia; Aryani, B.D., Bina Nusantara International, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Visual language is the mean to convey message through visual cues. Film, as an audio visual media, depends largely on visual language to tell its story. The comprehension of the story relies on the understanding of the audience concerning the visual cues brought forth in the film. The understanding of visual language is made by a consensus between film maker and society in general. But what happens if the audiences are children? Could children understand the visual language in films? What happens if they don’t? With this research we are going to look at how film makers uses visual language to tell their story to children in Indonesia Children’s film.Why Indonesia Children’s Film? Because though the production of Indonesia’s film has pick up the pace significantly, Indonesian Children’s Film still stay stationary. The lack of children viewer that watches Indonesian Children’s Film is the reason for this condition. With this research, using semiotic method, we are going try to identify whether the lack of the usage of visual language in Indonesia Children’s Film is related to the lack of viewers acceptance to the film. © 2015 Taylor and Francis Group, London.
Index Keywords: Behavioral research; Semiotics; Audio-visual media; Film-makers; Indonesia; Visual cues; Visual languages
